lines.text: Well, art is art, isn't it? Still, on the other hand, water is water. And east is east and west is west, and if you take cranberries and stew them like applesauce, they taste much more like prunes than rhubarb does. Now, uh... Now you tell me what you know.
How much would you charge to run into an open manhole?
Just the cover charge.
Well, drop in sometime.
Sewer.
Well, we cleaned that up pretty well.
Now read me the letter, Jamison.

[reading]
"Honorable Charles H. Hungadunga..."

[correcting him]
Hungerdunger.
[they say the "hung" syllable in unison]
Hoong.
Hungerdunger.
That's it, Hungerdunger.

[continues reading]
"... care of Hungerdunger, Hungerdunger, Hungerdunger, and McCormick."
You've left out a Hungerdunger. You left out the main one, too. Thought you could slip one over on me, didn't you, eh?
[pause]
All right, leave it out and put in a windshield wiper instead.
[Jamison nods and writes]
I tell you what you do, Jamison, I tell you what. Make it, uh, make it three windshield wipers and one Hungerdunger. They won't all be there when the letter arrives anyhow.

[rushes quickly through what he's just written]
"... Hungerdunger, Hungerdunger, Hungerdunger... and McCormick."
And McCormick.

[reading]
"Gentlemen, question mark."

[correcting him]
Gentlemen, question mark? Put it on the penultimate, not on the diphthongic. You wanna brush up on your Greek, Jamison. Well, get a Greek and brush up on him.

[reading]
"In re yours of the fifth inst..."
I see.
Now, uh... you said a lot of things here that I didn't think were important, so I just omitted them.
Well!
Hmm. Hmm. Hmm. Hmm.
[suddenly tries to hit Jamison with his switch, but misses; he falls]

[helps Spaulding up]
Oh, Captain! Good gracious! Oh, my.

[to Jamison]
So, you just omitted them, eh? You just omitted the body of the letter, that's all. You've just left out the body of the letter, that's all. Yours is not to reason why, Jamison. You've left out the body of the letter.
[pause]
All right, send it that way and tell them the body will follow.
[swings his switch indignantly]
Do you want the body in brackets?
No, it'll never get there in brackets. Put it in a box. Put it in a box and mark it, uh..."fragilly."
Mark it what?
Mark it fragilly. F-R-A-G... Look it up, Jamison, it's in the dictionary. Look under "fragile." Look under the table if you don't find it there.
One morning I shot an elephant in my pajamas. How he got in my pajamas, I don't know. Then we tried to remove the tusks. The tusks. That's not so easy to say. Tusks. You try it some time.
"tusks."

[shakes Chandler's hand]
My name is Spaulding. I've always wanted to meet you, Mr. Chandler. As I say, we tried to remove the tusks. But they were embedded so firmly we couldn't budge them. Of course, in Alabama the Tuscaloosa, but that is entirely ir-elephant to what I was talking about.
[Dictating a letter]
Gentlemen... question mark.

I'm sick of these conventional marriages. One woman and one man was good enough for your grandmother, but who wants to marry your grandmother? Nobody, not even your grandfather. Think! Think of the honeymoon! Strictly private. I wouldn't let another woman in on this. Well, maybe one or two. But, no men! I may not go myself.
[Jamison finishes reading the letter that Spaulding dictated to him]

[reading]
"Quotes, unquotes, and quotes."
That's three quotes?
Yes, sir.
Add another quote and make it a gallon. How much is it a gallon, Jamison?
Regards.

Regards. That's a fine letter, Jamison, that's an epic. That's dandy. Now, I want you to make two carbon copies of that letter and throw the original away. And when you get through with that, throw the carbon copies away. Just send a stamp, airmail, that's all. You may go, Jamison. I may go too.
Signor Ravelli's first selection will be "Somewhere My Love Lies Sleeping" with a male chorus.
You're the most beautiful woman I've ever seen, which doesn't say much for you.
Steel 186, Anaconda 74, American Can 138.

[taunting Roscoe Chandler]
Abie the fish man! Abie the fish man! Abie the fish man!

[asking Roscoe Chandler about his new identity]
How did you get to be Roscoe W. Chandler?
Say, how did you get to be an Italian?
Never mind that, whose confession is this?
[to Mrs. Rittenhouse and Mrs. Whitehead]
You know, you two girls have everything. You're tall and short and slim and stout and blonde and brunette. And that's just the kind of a girl I crave.
Oh, Captain Spaulding...
I'll attend to you later.
[turns back to the litter-bearers]
Don't try and pull that...
Oh, Captain Spaulding...

[she finally succeeds in getting his attention]
Why, you're one of the most beautiful women I've *ever* seen, and that's not saying much for you.
Captain Spaulding, Rittenhouse Manor is entirely at your disposal.
Well, I'm certainly grateful for this magnificent washout - er, turnout. And now I'd like to say a few words.
[sings]
Hello, I must be going/I cannot stay, I came to say I must be going/I'm glad I came, but just the same, I must be going, la-la!
[Tries to leave, the guests stop him]

[sings]
For my sake, you must stay/If you should go away/You'd spoil this party I am throwing.

[sings]
I'll stay a week or two/I'll stay the summer through/But I am telling you/I must be going
I used to know a fellow who looked exactly like you by the name of Emanuel Ravelli. Are you his brother?
I am Emanuel Ravelli.
You're Emanuel Ravelli?
I am Emanuel Ravelli.
Well, no wonder you look like him. But I still insist there is a resemblance.
Heh, heh, he thinks I look alike.
Well, if you do, it's a tough break for both of you.
Do you mind if I don't smoke?
[Spaulding has repeatedly told Jamison to take a letter to Spaulding's lawyers, but he has kept interrupting himself]
I say, take a letter to my lawyers!
Well I am taking it!
[long pause, as nothing has yet been written]
Honorable Charles H., uh, Hungerdunger, care of Hungerdunger, Hungerdunger, Hungerdunger, Hungerdunger, and McCormick... semicolon.
How do you spell semicolon?
All right, make it a comma.
[pause]
Honorable Charles. H. Hungerdunger, care of Hunger...
[rushes through the repetition]
... and McCormick.
[pause]
Gentlemen, question mark?
[grunts]
Do you want that, uh,
[grunt]
in the letter?
No, put that in an envelope.
[pause]
Now then. In re yours of the fifth inst., yours to hand and beg to rep... brackets...
[pause]
... We have gone over the ground carefully, and we seem to believe, i.e., to wit, e.g., in lieu, that, uh, despite all our... precautionary measures which have been involved...
[pause]
... uh, we seem to believe that it is hardly necessary for us to proceed unless we, uh, receive an ipso facto that is not negligible at this moment, quotes, unquotes, and quotes...
[pause]
... uh, hoping this finds you, I beg to remain...

[interrupting]
Hoping this finds him where?
Well, let him worry about that. Don't be so inquisitive, Jamison.
[insultingly]
Sneak.
[pause]
I say, hoping this finds you, I beg to remain, as of June 9th, cordially yours, regards. That's all, Jamison.

[to Mrs. Rittenhouse and Mrs. Whitehead]
What do you say, girls? What do you say? Are we all going to get married?
All of us?
All of us!
But, that's bigamy!
Yes, and it's big of me too.
Captain, this leaves me speechless.
Well, see that you remain that way.
Africa is God's country, and he can have it.
Say, how long has this been going on? Let's change the subject. Take the foreign situation. Take Abyssinia. I'll tell you, you take Abyssinia and I'll take a hot butterscotch sundae on rye bread.
Now tell me, Capt. Spaulding, you've been quite a traveler. What do you think about South America? I'm going there soon.
Is that so! Where're you going?
Uruguay.
Well, you go Uruguay and I'll go mine.

[to Arabella and John]
You know Conductor Hennessey, don't you?
Inspector.
Inspect her, yourself.
Tell me, what do you think of the traffic problem? What do you think of the marriage problem? What do you think of at night when you go to bed, you beast?
Play that song about the Irish chiropodist.
Irish chiropodist?
"My Fate Is In Your Hands".
Hooray for Captain Spaulding, the African explorer!
Did someone call me schnorrer?
Hooray, hooray, hooray!
He went into the jungle where all the monkeys throw nuts.
If I stay here, I'll go nuts.
Hooray, hooray, hooray! He put all his reliance / In courage and defiance / And risked his life for science.
Hey, hey!
He is the only white man who covered every acre...
I think I'll try and make her...
Hooray, hooray, hooray!
Why, you've got beauty, charm, money! You *have* got money, haven't you? Because if you haven't, we can quit right now.

If I were Eugene O'Neill, I could tell you what I really think of you two. You know, you're very fortunate the Theatre Guild isn't putting this on. And so is the Guild! Pardon me while I have a "Strange Interlude".
[Walks forward, speaks directly to the camera]
Why you, couple of baboons. What make you think I'd marry either one of you. Strange how the wind blows tonight.
How happy I could be with either of these two if both of them just went away.

[while Ravelli is playing the same piano part over and over]
Say, if you get near a song, play it!
I can't think of the finish.
That's strange and I can't think of anything else.
You know what I think, I think I went past it.
Well, if you come around again, jump off.
Oh, Hives! Hives! Where are you? Turn on the lights.
Mrs. Rittenhouse, did you lose that fish again?
I can't understand what's delaying that coffee pot.

[Speaking directly at the camera]
Well, all the jokes can't be good. You've got to expect that once in awhile.

[During a "Strange Interlude" monologue]
Here I am talking of parties. I came down here for a party. What happens? Nothing. Not even ice cream. The gods look down and laugh. This would be a better world for children, if the parents had to eat the spinach.
I was outside the cabin smoking some meat. There wasn't a cigar store in the neighborhood!
Pardon me Mrs. Rittenhouse, did you lose a fish?
Capt. Spaulding, the guest of honor, will have the green duplex with the two baths.
Two, madame?
Why, yes! I think the Capt. would like two baths, don't you?
Well, if he's just returned from Africa, he may need two baths.
Well, Sis, it looks as if we yield the social honor of the season to Mrs. Rittenhouse.
Well, isn't there something we can do?
We might shoot ourselves.
I'd rather shoot Mrs. Rittenhouse.
May I present Mr. Parker.
Oh, of the, eh, Massachusetts Parkers?
Why, no.
Oh, then the, eh, Southern Parkers?
Oh, no, the Central Parkers. You know, the, eh, benches and trees.
I see!
[Mrs. Whitehead leaves]
Meow! Oh, I don't like that woman!
Do you really love me?
Why don't you marry me and find out.
Marry you? Heh! On what! Last year I sold two paintings. One at a hundred and one at fifty. Could we live on a hundred and fifty dollars a year?
Well, we wouldn't need any money. I've got a charge account in every shop on Fifth Avenue.
Well, if I had any brains, I'd give up painting and get a regular job. You know, I had a cousin who made $50,000 on Wall Street last year.
I don't want to marry your cousin. I'm a darn fool. I want to marry you.
Mrs. Rittenhouse, ever since I met you, I've swept you off my feet.
Something has been throbbing within me. Oh, it's been beating like the incessant tom-tom in the primitive jungle. Something that I must ask you.
What is it, Capt.?
Would you wash out a pair of socks for me?

[On his knees]
I love you, that's all. I love you. I've always thought of you.
[In walks Mrs. Whitehead]
Capt., Mrs. Whitehead.
I beg your pardon? I beg your pardon? Am I intruding?
Are you intruding? Just when I had her on the five yard line.
We three would make an ideal couple. Why you've got beauty, charm, money! You have got money, haven't you? Because if you haven't, we can quit right now.
The Capt. is charming, now, isn't he?
I'm fascinated! Right on the arm.
Now, please, Chandler is my name. Roscoe W. Chandler.
Yeah, but I don't care about the name. You see, some place I met you before; because, your face is a very familiar. Now, wait, let me see. Were you ever in Sing-Sing?
Listen, here. I have me a check for $5,000. Now, I give it to you. Here.
Hey, is it good?
Well, of course it is good. Who would give me a bad check?
I would!
Oh, Mr. Raviola!
Ravelli, Ravelli.
Oh, eh, Mr. Ravelli, I want you to do something for me.
How mucha we make? We maka nothing. The first thing you know we gonna live on a charity. Then, we go to the old ladies home. How do you like that?
[Harpo smiles]
No-no. That's a no good!
How 'bout playing some bridge? You play bridge?
I play bridge a little.
What do you play for?
Oh, we just play for small stakes.
And French fry potatoes?

[Bridge game]
How do you want to play? Honest?
Well, I hope so!

[Describing his trip to Africa]
The elks, on the other hand, live up in the hills. And in the spring, they come down for their annual convention. It is very interesting to watch them come to the water hole. And you should see them run when they find it is only a water hole! What they're looking for is an alcohol.

[Describing his trip to Africa]
We took some pictures of the native girls; but, they weren't developed. But, we're going back again in a coupla weeks.
Hooray for Capt. Spaulding! Three cheers for Capt. Spaulding! Three cheers for Capt. Spaulding! Three cheers...
[Harpo arrives with three chairs]
No one asked for the chairs. Put them right were you found them. Now, get out.
Play the song about Montreal.
Montreal?
I'm a Dreamer, Montreal.
Now, Mrs. Rittenrotten.
Mrs. Rittenhouse.
Yes, a slight error.

[In a monotone voice]
No trains will be sold after the magazines leave the depot.
Leave it to me! I'll throw some light on this subject.
[the lights go out]
The crooks! The crooks! They're escaping. Follow me men! Never mind the men, just the women!

[singing]
When we pet, close in your arms you hold me. I forget, all that my mother told me...
If I were a man, you'd resent that!
Put that in your pipe and smoke it.
A more dastardly crack I've ever heard! I wish I was back in the jungle where men are monkeys.
I'll get Capt. Spaulding. He'll get to the bottom of this!
I haven't been on the case five minutes and there's another painting gone. I bet its not even five minutes. I bet its not over three.
[Searches his pants]
Now they've got my watch! This is going too far. It wasn't going and now its gone.
Now, if we can find the left-handed person that painted this, we'll have "The Trial of Mary Dugan" with sound.
Well, I saw that.
Would you mind going out and crossing the boulevard when the lights are against you.
Well, I tell ya Capt., you see, my idea of a house is something nice and a small and comfortable.
That's the way I feel about it. I don't want anything elaborate. Just a little place that I can call home and tell the wife I won't be there for dinner.
Well, look. All you gotta do is open the door, step outside and there you are.
There you are? There you are, where?
Outside.
Well, suppose you want to get back in again?
You had no right to go out.
Yeh, right there's the rooms. This is your room. This is a my room. And this is the maid's room.
Oh, I'd have to go through your room?
Ha-ha-ha-ha-ha! Ah, that's alright. I won't be in it.
Say, Ravelli, you, eh, you couldn't put the maid in your room, eh?
What makes you think I couldn't?
Well, there's going to be a lot of traffic in there. I can see that.
You know, I'd buy you a parachute if I thought it wouldn't open.
Ha-ha-ha!
[points at his feet]
Hey, I got pair of shoes!
